level.heading: Definitions.
level.text: Except as otherwise provided, for purposes of this chapter:

level.heading: Appropriate congressional committees
level.text: The term "appropriate congressional committees" means: -
The Committee on Appropriations of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Appropriations of the Senate;
The Committee on Economic and Educational Opportunities of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Labor and Human Resources of the Senate; and
The Committee on Government Reform and Oversight of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Governmental Affairs of the Senate.

level.heading: Authority
level.text: The term "Authority" means the District of Columbia Financial Responsibility and Management Assistance Authority established under § 47-391.01(a).

level.heading: Average daily attendance
level.text: The term "average daily attendance" means the aggregate attendance of students of the school during the period divided by the number of days during the period in which:
The school is in session; and
The students of the school are under the guidance and direction of teachers.

level.heading: Average daily membership
level.text: The term "average daily membership" means the aggregate enrollment of students of the school during the period divided by the number of days during the period in which:
The school is in session; and
The students of the school are under the guidance and direction of teachers.

level.heading: Board of Education
level.text: The term "Board of Education" means the Board of Education of the District of Columbia.

level.heading: Board of Trustees
level.text: The term "Board of Trustees" means the governing board of a public charter school, the members of which are selected pursuant to the charter granted to the school and in a manner consistent with this chapter.

level.heading: Consensus Commission
level.text: The term "Consensus Commission" means the Commission on Consensus Reform in the District of Columbia public schools established under subchapter VIII of this chapter.

level.heading: Core curriculum
level.text: The term "core curriculum" means the concepts, factual knowledge, and skills that students in the District of Columbia should learn in kindergarten through grade 12 in academic content areas, including, at a minimum, English, mathematics, science, and history.

level.heading: District of Columbia Council
level.text: The term "District of Columbia Council" means the Council of the District of Columbia established pursuant to § 1-204.01.

level.heading: In general
level.text: The term "District of Columbia Government" means the government of the District of Columbia, including:
Any department, agency, or instrumentality of the government of the District of Columbia;
Any independent agency of the District of Columbia established under part F of title IV of the District of Columbia Home Rule Act;
Any other agency, board, or commission established by the Mayor or the District of Columbia Council;
The courts of the District of Columbia;
The District of Columbia Council; and

Any other agency, public authority, or public nonprofit corporation that has the authority to receive moneys directly or indirectly from the District of Columbia (other than moneys received from the sale of goods, the provision of services, or the loaning of funds to the District of Columbia).

level.heading: Exception
level.text: The term "District of Columbia Government" neither includes the Authority nor a public charter school.

level.heading: District of Columbia Government Retirement System
level.text: The term "District of Columbia Government retirement system" means the retirement programs authorized by the District of Columbia Council or the Congress for employees of the District of Columbia Government.

level.heading: In general
level.text: The term "District of Columbia public school" means a public school in the District of Columbia that offers classes:
At any of the grade levels from prekindergarten through grade 12; or
Leading to a secondary school diploma, or its recognized equivalent.

level.heading: Exception
level.text: The term "District of Columbia public school" does not include a public charter school.

level.heading: Districtwide assessments
level.text: The term "districtwide assessments" means a variety of assessment tools and strategies (including individual student assessments under subparagraph (E)(ii) of this paragraph administered by the Superintendent to students enrolled in District of Columbia public schools and public charter schools that:
Are aligned with the District of Columbia's content standards and core curriculum;
Provide coherent information about student attainment of such standards;
Are used for purposes for which such assessments are valid, reliable, and unbiased, and are consistent with relevant nationally recognized professional and technical standards for such assessments;
Involve multiple up-to-date measures of student performance, including measures that assess higher order thinking skills and understanding; and
Provide for:
The participation in such assessments of all students;
Individual student assessments for students that fail to reach minimum acceptable levels of performance;

The reasonable adaptations and accommodations for students with special needs (as defined in paragraph (32) of this section) necessary to measure the achievement of such students relative to the District of Columbia's content standards; and

The inclusion of limited-English proficient students, who shall be assessed, to the extent practicable, in the language and form most likely to yield accurate and reliable information regarding such students' knowledge and abilities.

level.heading: Electronic data transfer system
level.text: The term "electronic data transfer system" means a computer-based process for the maintenance and transfer of student records designed to permit the transfer of individual student records among District of Columbia public schools and public charter schools.

level.heading: Elementary school
level.text: The term "elementary school" means an institutional day or residential school that provides elementary education, as determined under District of Columbia law.

level.heading: Eligible applicant
level.text: The term "eligible applicant" means a person, including a private, public, or quasi-public entity, or an institution of higher education (as defined in § 1201(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. § 1141(a) [repealed]), that seeks to establish a public charter school in the District of Columbia.

level.heading: Eligible chartering authority
level.text: The term "eligible chartering authority" means any of the following:
The Board of Education;
The Public Charter School Board; or
Any one entity designated as an eligible chartering authority by enactment of a bill by the District of Columbia Council after April 26, 1996.

level.heading: Family resource center
level.text: The term "family resource center" means an information desk:

Located in a District of Columbia public school or a public charter school serving a majority of students whose family income is not greater than 185 percent of the income official poverty line (as defined by the Office of Management and Budget, and revised annually in accordance with § 673(2) of the Community Services Block Grant Act applicable to a family of the size involved (42 U.S.C. § 9902(3)); and
Which links students and families to local resources and public and private entities involved in child care, adult education, health and social services, tutoring, mentoring, and job training.

level.heading: Individual career path
level.text: The term "individual career path" means a program of study that provides a secondary school student the skills necessary to compete in the 21st century workforce.

level.heading: Literacy
level.text: The term "literacy" means:

In the case of a minor student, such student's ability to read, write, and speak in English, and compute and solve problems at levels of proficiency necessary to function in society, to achieve such student's goals, and develop such student's knowledge and potential; and

In the case of an adult, such adult's ability to read, write, and speak in English, and compute and solve problems at levels of proficiency necessary to function on the job and in society, to achieve such adult's goals, and develop such adult's knowledge and potential.

level.heading: Long-term reform plan
level.text: The term "long-term reform plan" means the plan submitted by the Superintendent under § 38-1801.01.

level.heading: Mayor
level.text: The term "Mayor" means the Mayor of the District of Columbia.

level.heading: Metrobus and Metrorail Transit System
level.text: The term "Metrobus and Metrorail Transit System" means the bus and rail systems administered by the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority.

level.heading: Minor student
level.text: The term "minor student" means an individual who:
Is enrolled in a District of Columbia public school or a public charter school; and
Is not beyond the age of compulsory school attendance, as prescribed in §§ 38-201 and 38-202.

level.heading: Nonprofit Corporation Act
level.text: The term "Nonprofit Corporation Act" means Chapter 4 of Title 29.

level.heading: Nonresident student
level.text: The term "nonresident student" means:

An individual under the age of 18 who is enrolled in a District of Columbia public school or a public charter school, and does not have a parent, guardian, custodian, or primary care giver, as determined pursuant to Chapter 3 of this title [§ 38-302 et seq.], residing in the District of Columbia; or
An individual who is age 18 or older and is enrolled in a District of Columbia public school or public charter school, and does not reside in the District of Columbia.

level.heading: Office of the State Superintendent of Education or OSSE
level.text: The term "Office of the State Superintendent of Education" or "OSSE" means the Office of the State Superintendent of Education established by § 38-2601.

level.heading: Parent
level.text: The term "parent" means a person who has custody of a child, and who:
Is a natural parent of the child;
Is a stepparent of the child;
Has adopted the child; or
Is appointed as a guardian for the child by a court of competent jurisdiction.

level.heading: Petition
level.text: The term "petition" means a written application.

level.heading: Promotion gate
level.text: The term "promotion gate" means the criteria, developed by the Superintendent and approved by the Board of Education, that are used to determine student promotion at different grade levels. Such criteria shall include student achievement on districtwide assessments established under subchapter III of this chapter.

level.heading: Public charter school
level.text: The term "public charter school" means a publicly funded school in the District of Columbia that:
Is established pursuant to subchapter II of this chapter; and
Except as provided under §§ 38-1802.12(d)(5) and 38-1802.13(c)(5) is not a part of the District of Columbia public schools.

level.heading: Public Charter School Board
level.text: The term "Public Charter School Board" means the Public Charter School Board established under § 38-1802.14.

level.heading: Secondary school
level.text: The term "secondary school" means an institutional day or residential school that provides secondary education, as determined by District of Columbia law, except that such term does not include any education beyond grade 12.

level.heading: Student with special needs
level.text: The term "student with special needs" means a student who is a child with a disability as provided in § 602(a)(1) of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (20 U.S.C. § 1401(a)(1)) or a student who is an individual with a disability as provided in § 7(8) of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 706(8) [29 U.S.C. § 705(20)]).

level.heading: Superintendent
level.text: The term "Superintendent" means the Superintendent of the District of Columbia public schools.

level.heading: Teacher
level.text: The term "teacher" means any person employed as a teacher by the Board of Education or by a public charter school.

level.heading: Cross References
level.text: Disposition of certain school property, preference for public charter school, see § 47-392.25.

level.heading: Section References
level.text: This section is referenced in § 5-132.01 and § 47-392.25.

D.C. Law 16-268 added par. (24A).
D.C. Law 17-20 added par. (25A).
D.C. Law 18-378, in par. (24A), substituted "Chapter 4 of Title 29" for "subchapter I of Chapter 3 of Title 29".

level.heading: Temporary Amendment of Section
level.text: Section 3(a) of D.C. Laws 13-199 in subsec. (25)(A), substituted "parent, guardian or custodian" for "parent".
Section 6(b) of D.C. Laws 13-427 provided that the act shall expire after 225 days of its having taken effect.
Section 3(a) of D.C. Law 14-38, in subsec. (25)(A) is amended by striking the word "parent" and inserting the phrase "parent, guardian or custodian" in its place.
Section 6(b) of D.C. Law 14-38 provided that the act shall expire after 225 days of its having taken effect.
Section 3(a) of D.C. Law 15-67, in par. (25)(A), substituted "parent, guardian or custodian" for "parent".
Section 6(b) of D.C. Law 15-67 provided that the act shall expire after 225 days of its having taken effect.

level.heading: Legislative History of Law 14-38
level.text: Law 14-38, the "Public School Enrollment Integrity Temporary Amendment Act of 2001", was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 14-242, which was retained by Council. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on June 5, 2001, and June 26, 2001, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on July 12, 2001, it was assigned Act No. 14-100 and transmitted to both Houses of Congress for its review. D.C. Law 14-38 became effective on October 13, 2001.

level.heading: Legislative History of Law 15-67
level.text: Law 15-67, the "Public School Enrollment Integrity Clarification Temporary Amendment Act of 2003", was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 15-433, and was retained by Council. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on September 16, 2003, and October 7, 2003, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on October 24, 2003, it was assigned Act No. 15-185 and transmitted to both Houses of Congress for its review. D.C. Law 15-67 became effective on February 6, 2004.

level.heading: Legislative History of Law 15-348
level.text: Law 15-348, the "Public School Enrollment Integrity Clarification and Board of Education Honoraria Amendment Act of 2004", was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 15-411 which was referred to the Committee Education, Libraries and Recreation. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on December 7, 2004, and December 21, 2004, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on January 22, 2005, it was assigned Act No. 15-742 and transmitted to both Houses of Congress for its review. D.C. Law 15-348 became effective on April 13, 2005.

level.text: "Part F of title IV of the District of Columbia Home Rule Act," referred to in (10)(A)(ii), is part F of title IV of the Act of December 24, 1973, 87 Stat. 774, Pub. L. 93-198 which is codified as §§ 1-204.61 through 1-204.66.
